Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story:
I glanced at the clock as I finished brushing out the client’s hair, my hands trembling slightly. The golden tone she’d requested looked a shade too brassy under the salon lights, and I saw her lips press into a thin line as she stared at her reflection. “Is everything alright?” I asked, forcing a smile, but my mind was already racing. It was almost sunset, and I hadn’t yet lit the lamp at my home altar or offered my evening prayers—something I’d promised myself never to skip, no matter how busy work became. 

She hesitated, then quietly admitted she’d hoped for something softer, less bold. My heart sank. As a hairdresser, I knew I needed to listen, reassure her, maybe even redo the colour if she wished. But the minutes were slipping away, and the thought of missing my daily ritual gnawed at me. My family’s expectations, my own faith, the peace I found in those few moments of prayer—all tugged at me from one side, while my professional pride and duty to my client pulled from the other. I stood there, caught between the mirror and the memory of the lamp waiting to be lit, unsure which role to answer first.
